support.note: Pale red imbedded conglomerate and sandstone

layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with a roman-letter inscription in four lines reading vertically downwards. The first and final line in the inscription are the final words of the middle lines due to lack of space. This layout is similar to the Brynkir inscription and shows the letter-cutters' understanding of Roman convention for inscriptions of more than one line to be right-justified a certain height above the ground. A corresponding ogham insciption starts at the bottom left edge continuing upwards along the top of the stone, and ending one third of the way along the top. Both inscriptions are carved some with a bevel . (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 160-1).

handDesc.handNote: The letters seem to reflect a higher degree of care put into the carving of TURPILLI, the name of the dead, than in the rest given more cramped letters in the rest of the inscription. In the ogham inscription, the fourth letter seems to be X, a variation of a character to represent P (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 160-1).

div.p: Ogham: 'of Turpillius (or Turpilus), the son of Trillunus'
Roman: 'of Turpilius (or Turpilus). He lies here, the son of Trilunus Dunocatus'

item.p: The ogham inscription consists of the same commemoration as the roman-letter inscription, except that the latter adds the formaula hic iacit 'here lies' and an extra name (Dunacatos) at the end. Dating depends on the significance of the use of U for /u/>/ö/ in TVRPILLI... Assuming that the name DVNOCATI is Irish; if it were British, the insription would be very early and probably incompatible with the epigraphic date... The first name is either Turpilius or Turpilus both well attested. They are orignially pejorative Latin names from turpis and would have been borne by a Welshman or an Irishman (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 161). The ogham corresponding to TRILVNI has been read in various ways including T[RA]LL[O]NI but TRILLUNI is more likely. Various Welsh etymologies can be suggested, such as 'of three forms' (Rhys 1879, 381-2), 'very abundant'(trylawn), 'very strong' (trylonn or 'of three moons', perhaps referrring to the time of birth (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 162). It is also possible that TRILVNI is a mis-transcription of the ogham with the L symbol potentially really representing a BB in TRIBBUNI and BB standing in for /b/ or P. The ogham inscription is notable for containing the symbol 'X', a rare attempt to represent the Latin P... Dunacatus is made up of Irish elements, but is a name not found in ogham inscriptions, though it developed later into the Old Irish name 'Dúnchad' (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 161-2).

Corresponding to the ogham inscription's MOSAC (as read and interpreted by Macalister 1945, 315), the Latin inscription has PVVERI instead of Classical Latin pueri, 'of the boy'. Here the VV denotes the British pronunciation /uṷ/. Charles Thomas (1994, 124) suggests that TRILVNI was intended for TRIBUNI, as in CIIC. 476/Okasha 1993: no. 45, TRIBVNI (Latin tribunus or personal name Tribunus), with Roman B miscopied as L, and suggests that it is the same name as Triphun in the Dyfed king-list... DVNOCATI (also attested in Britain in CIIC. 457/Okasha 1993: no. 18 DVNOCATI with Irish patronymic) can be the ancestor of either Irish Dúnchad or OW Din(a)cat, MW Din(o)gat, both well attested personal names. It is probably Irish since /u:/ has already changed via /ü:/ to /i:/ in Britonnic in the 'middle of the fifth century' according to Jackson... The Primitive Irish genetive would be *Dūnacatōs, but Latinate -I can be expected to replace the Irish -OS in Britain. It is less likely that DVNOCATI is a place-name (functioning like SALICIDVNI in the Llywel inscription) although a place in south Wales called Brehant Din Cat, 'guttur receptaculum pugnae' is mentioned by the ninth-century Breton hagiographer Wrmonoc. (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 161-2).
